info.headline: Flood Advisory issued December 26 at 5:18AM EST until December 27 at 7:00AM EST by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 1 PM EST THIS AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues. * WHERE...Central and southern Henderson County and Polk County in North Carolina * WHEN...Until 100 PM EST Tuesday. * IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood- prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 505 AM EST, Over the past few hours, showers have weakened across Henderson and Polk counties, allowing smaller streams to crest, including Bat Fork Creek and the headwaters of Mud Creek. However, an axis of showers and thunderstorms is approaching the area from the southwest, capable of producing additional moderate to heavy rainfall. This rainfall will occur on top of 2-4 inches of rain which accumulated since yesterday morning. This rainfall will exacerbate high flow conditions and likely cause new rises on elevated streams, or cause rising streams to crest at higher levels. As a result, nuisance flood conditions are expected to return or become more widespread, with some Minor Flooding or more significant flooding of flood-prone areas possible. Furthermore, it will take some time for larger streams to crest even without additional significant rainfall, including Mud Creek near Hendersonville and the Green River in Polk County. Therefore, the Flood Advisory will continue into the early afternoon. Mud Creek from Crail Farm Rd to Erkwood Dr to White St and S Center Plaza to the Oklawaha Greenway continues to rise and is exceeding its banks, flooding adjacent low-lying areas. The following streamgauge is above Action/Advisory Stage, resulting in nuisance flooding along Mud Creek... ID: MNMN7 NAME: at N Main St, 1 N Hendersonville CURRENT STAGE: 12.32 feet ACTION/ADVISORY STAGE: 11.5 MINOR FLOOD STAGE: 14.0 TREND: Rising Slowly FORECAST: Mud Creek is expected to continue to approach 13 feet over the next few hours and may exceed Minor Flood Stage later Tuesday morning. - Additional rainfall amounts of 1 to 2 inches is expected through Tuesday afternoon, with isolated totals exceeding 3 inches possible. Intense rainfall rates may result in an acceleration of stream rises as upper soils are already saturated from earlier rainfall. This may cause flash flooding to develop and a Flash Flood Warning may be necessary. If rapid stream rises are observed, avoid all low-lying areas near streams and be prepared to seek higher ground. - Some locations that may experience nuisance flooding include... Hendersonville, Columbus, Flat Rock, Etowah, Mountain Home, Laurel Park, Tryon, Saluda, Dupont State Forest, Valley Hill, Dana, Lake Adger, East Flat Rock, Mill Spring, Tuxedo, Crab Creek and Green Creek.
info.instruction: In hilly terrain there are hundreds of low water crossings which are potentially dangerous in heavy rain. Do not attempt to cross flooded roads. Find an alternate route.
